caption: The opening date and time are for reference only. I went on 01/14 and 1/16, both days are locked up and no answer when called. Today, 01/17/2025, there is still no answer on the phone. I give up. So irresponsible. It‚Äôs not right. I am giving a lecture later this year on how this man stole, cheated and robbed China off many treasured artifacts. I just want to have a look  at this place he built with the wealth he unashamedly gathered.  Called again before leaving Paris (01/19/2025). Still no answer. Compared to Musee Chernuschi nearby, this place is totally unworthy.
So so beautiful! I love this mix of Chinese and European architecture next to each other. You can see the difference, that makes the contrast so interesting. Definitely worth some pictures.

In the heart of the Plaine Monceau, a Paris neighborhood which has undoubtedly the largest mansions in m¬≤, is an amazing Chinese Pagoda.  Arrived in 1902 in Paris, ChingTsaiLoo is an art dealer who has known a dazzling success. He bought a mansion built in 1880, classic style, in order to work a few steps from Parc Monceau. Mr. Loo was lucky, the owners were not asked to have a building permit at this time.  The architect Fernand Bloch is then responsible for transforming this 19th century building into a beautiful pagoda of Chinese inspiration. The mansion is raised by two floors, the roof was rebuilt, and the entire building painted in red.  The construction was achieved in 1926, which obviously has led many complaints and even a neighbourhood petition for demolition. In vain‚Ä¶ the ‚ÄúHouse Loo‚Äù is still standing up today. And although it was sold in 2011, its activity keeps going according to the wishes of its founder, namely to be a cultural bridge between France and China.  It is now a private museum, which offers throughout the year exhibitions and shows (and even offers spaces privatized). The only opportunity to discover the magnificent interior decor typically Chinese of this pagoda.
Incredible building on rue de Courcelles. (Difficult to say more as never Ahmad a chance to visit the inside‚Ä¶ looking forward to it)
Quite place , mix culture Vietnam and western
Please review you opening times online. I would have loved to visit it but I lost my trip just to find the place closed. A bit disappointed.
It is said it‚Äôs open from 9am on Mondays, but when we went there past 11am today, still closed. Rang the bell no answer. Called them only auto answers. A bit disappointed. :(

A UFO in a Hausmanian Paris, this pagoda is worth the detour  Maison Loo, located in the heart of the Monceau plain between the 8th and 17th arrondissements, is an unusual architectural treasure. Revisited in 1926, this old residence stands today as a private museum, a building of a man's love for his country of origin, China, in the heart of Paris.

The private tour during Asian Arts Week. The exterior is magnificent, the interior decor is incredible. The walls are richly decorated in black and red lacquer in the best Chinese tradition. The ceilings are also magnificent. It is a must to visit for all lovers of Asian art.

This Chinese-style Buddhist building is a private Asian art museum called Maison de Loup, and was designated as a French cultural heritage site in 2002. It stands out even more because it is surrounded by Paris's chic Haussmann architecture. It is said that Ching Tsai Loo, a wealthy Chinese Asian art collector, originally had it built by remodeling an Ottoman building around 1925. The museum's collection includes 1,300 books, 3,000 exhibition catalogs, and 3,000 rare photographs.

Great experience despite a very significant price change (from free to finally ‚Ç¨15). No student/youth discount granted. Otherwise the collections are magnificent and the place is exceptional! Good but not worth the price!

After checking the schedules on Google and 40 minutes of travel, I notice that the place is closed. We rang the doorbell of the guard and got no answer. Please correct the opening hours on the internet and communicate whether or not you can visit this place.

Loo's house, commonly known as Paris Pagoda, is a unique building with Asian characteristics right in the heart of the luxurious and very French 8th district. The architecture from outside to inside is a collection of typical quintessence and symbols of the East: curved tiled roofs, red walls, symbols of the 12 zodiac animals, letter patterns on door frames, lacquered screens, ‚Ä¶ Everything is luxurious and elegant, harmonious and highly aesthetic. Any corner of the building bears the mark of history-art-culture. Truly respect the person who created this architectural work nearly 100 years ago.

Very beautiful building with atypical architecture compared to the neighborhood. The building has, I think, remained as is without necessarily any renovation/modernization work (unless I am mistaken). It‚Äôs a shame that we can‚Äôt visit it or that it won‚Äôt be reinvested.

We are in Paris with a fine example of what Asian architecture can produce. China in this case is very nicely represented here! The work is certainly not well known enough and yet it is worth the detour Parisians or curious tourists will be delighted to discover the building üá®üáµüëç! Review published in April 2022 and I don't understand why it is no longer visible, I hope it will work this time and that Google will make it visible again üëå.
Very surprising building in the heart of Paris, the colors and architecture are magnificent. To have.

Close to Parc Monceau and the Cernuschi Museum. Very beautiful pagoda from 1926, with details in every corner. Currently closed. But it also deserves to be seen for its exterior. So deserving of restoration and opening to the public.

A must see!! Gorgeous. Nice contrast in Paris. You can only see the outside... and it's worth it! There are exhibitions, but they are private. This "pagoda" was built on an existing mansion by Mr. Loo who came to settle in Paris while loving his China!! He had two Loves... his China and Paris. He was able to bring and impose his "Chinese note" since he had escaped the obligations of the building permit!!  From memory, this dates back to 1926.

A magnificent discovery, a warm welcome, exceptional pieces, of incredible beauty, breathtaking details, go there with your eyes closed üåü I would have liked to see other rooms, and more pieces üíì ‚Ä¶
How lucky to have been able to discover this magnificent monument in the middle of Paris! An extraordinary discovery on the occasion of the Asian spring.  Truly superb!

Like many Parisians and neighbors, we dreamed of discovering the Red Pagoda on rue de Courcelles and thanks to Printemps Asiatique we were able to do it this Saturday. The interior is magnificent, lacquered paintings, coffered ceiling. Perfect setting for exhibitors of Asian arts, just like Mr. Loo, owner of this pagoda in the 1920s.
The Chinese architecture is there, recognizable with its typical roof. But it is clearly abandoned and in need of renovation.  If my review and photos helped you, please give me a thumbs up üëç
